translated: 3. The Sutra of the Appearance of Light, Scroll 3
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter on Impermanence, Part 2
Although one may live a hundred years, they will die in the end, oppressed by old age,
and the bonds of illness will reach their limit.

In the past, the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Garden in the country of Shravasti, widely expounding the Dharma teachings for the various beings such as gods, humans, dragons, ghosts, and so forth.

At that time, the mother of King Prasenajit of the country, who was over 120 years old, suddenly fell seriously ill, incurable by medicine, and unable to be saved by the spirits. She passed away after a night.
The king and his ministers gave her a proper funeral, offering oil, ghee, flowers, and incense for every rite. She was placed in a shrine and guarded by people.

After the funeral, they returned to where the Buddha was. Following the king's usual practice, they removed their five adornments and paid homage at the Buddha's feet. The Buddha ordered them to sit and asked:
Where have you come from? Your clothes are dusty and your appearance has changed. What have you done to be like this?
The king said to the Buddha:
The senior queen of the country, who is over 120 years old, recently fell seriously ill and suddenly passed away.
We have just finished sending her coffin to the burial ground, and now we have returned to the city to pay our respects to the World-Honored One.
The Buddha, with the wisdom of the three insights, knew but asked:
What do you think, great king!
Is there anyone born in the world who will not die?
The king said to the Buddha:
No one born in the world will not die.
The Buddha told the king:
From ancient times to the present, there are five great fears that cannot be avoided:
The law of aging, wanting to avoid aging, this is impossible;
The law of sickness, wanting to avoid sickness, this is impossible;
The law of death, wanting to avoid death, this is impossible;ğŸ”½The law of destruction, wanting to avoid destruction, this is impossible;
The law of exhaustion, wanting to avoid exhaustion, this is impossible.
This is what is meant, Your Majesty!

These five unobtainable things do not make an appointment with people. All things are impermanent and difficult to stay for a long time. One day passes, and the human lifespan is also like this. Like the flow of the five rivers day and night without rest, the swiftness of the human lifespan is also like this.

At that time, the World-Honored One gradually spoke the subtle Dharma with King Prasenajit, discussing the essentials of irreversibility. The topics of discussion were the discussion of giving, the discussion of precepts, the discussion of rebirth in the heavens, the impure thoughts of desire, and the great suffering of defilements.
Your Majesty should know:

When born, old age comes, sickness has no luster, union must part, this is the constant Dharma of the world, like lightning flashing before the eyes, striking a stone to produce fire, human life is more fleeting than this, what is there to enjoy?
The Dharma of decay and change, wanting to make it last for a long time, this is not possible.

At that time, the World-Honored One, for the sake of future sentient beings, investigated the root and branches of this matter, and manifested great illumination, also causing the true Dharma to remain in the world for a long time.
At that time, the World-Honored One, in the midst of the great assembly, spoke this verse to King Prasenajit:
Although one may live for a hundred years, one still dies and passes away, oppressed by old age,
and at the end, afflicted by illness.
The Buddha told the great king:
The world is all like this, with no permanence. All will return to death, with no escape.
In the past, kings, buddhas, true persons, and sages with the five supernatural powers have all passed away, none able to remain;
in vain one grieves for the deceased. Do not be lazy in accumulating blessings, for blessings will follow the departed spirit, like sending provisions to a farmer.
Because of this, the king should extensively establish meritorious deeds. Blessings assist people, like relying on a strong staff.

Having spoken this, the king and the four groups of followers who had gathered there were all delighted, forgetting their worries and dispelling their afflictions, suddenly enlightened. They then rose from their seats, circumambulated the Buddha three times, made obeisance, and departed.
This day has already passed, and life accordingly diminishes, like a fish in shallow water,
what joy is there in this?
Once the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park in the kingdom of Shravasti.

At that time, the southern ocean suddenly surged with a great flood, exceeding the boundaries of the ocean. There were three large fish that followed the rising current to shallow water and said to each other:
We three fish are in a perilous place where the floodwaters have not yet receded. We should go upstream to return to the great ocean.

There was a water-bound boat that could not be crossed. The first fish, with all its strength, jumped over the boat, while the second fish was able to cross by clinging to grass. The third fish, with its energy exhausted, was caught by a hunter.
At that time, the hunter spoke this verse:
First, I worry that it has not yet happened, and I will surely be injured.
Relying on the grass to plan for the present, that life will escape death.
The two fish both escaped, saving their fragile lives,
The fool guards the small water pond, and suffers hardship from the hunter.

At that time, the World-Honored One, with his pure divine eye free from defilements, saw the three fish chased by the waves, with two fish saved and one fish suffering, and also saw the hunter speaking this verse.

Because of this cause and condition, he sought out the root and basis, and for the sake of future sentient beings, he manifested great illumination, and also caused the true Dharma to remain in the world for a long time. He then gathered the great assembly and spoke this verse:
This day has already passed, and life then decreases accordingly, like a fish with little water,
What joy is there in this?

The days that have passed refers to the fact that whether one is a ká¹£atriya, brÄhman, elder, or householder, whether one is young, middle-aged, or old, all share in the passing away of this day, with day and night not stopping, and life changing, the body becoming emaciated, the qi declining, and strength exhausted, faster than that.

Like a fish in little water, or a flying bird in the sky, a crane in the Ganges, a white heron, a stork, a blue crane, a water crow, or a black chicken, one is also caught by worldly men and women, hunters, nets, and snares, living in shallow water with myriad worries for a single life, receiving a body in the water and losing life in the water, with myriad sufferings difficult to seek, what joy is there?
Therefore it is said, Like a fish in little water, what joy is there?
The departed do not return, day and night diligently exerting, the fish is in a raging fire,
born suffering, dying in calamity.
Formerly the Buddha was in the realm of Magadha, at the site of the well-conquered enlightenment, gathering the practitioners.

Those dwelling in high mountains, either in deep caves hiding their forms and not coming out, yet that practitioner practices the Way according to the time, observing the seasonal qi. When spring arrives, they observe that all the trees are budding, their color like crystal, gradually unfolding into flowers, and they see the water in the ditches flowing clear and still, without any sound.
At that time, the practitioner thinks to themselves:
The time is not to be wasted, and all things are born together.

At that time, the practitioner goes down the mountain to the village, begging for food from house to house. They see the men and women eating and drinking happily, enjoying each other's company. The practitioner asks:
Who are these people?
The others reply:
They are from such-and-such village, such-and-such family, with such-and-such surname. The son of such-and-such family is born to such-and-such father.
At that time, the practitioner thinks to themselves again:
Now, all these inner things are all pregnant and lactating.
Knowing that all things are growing day by day, they return to the deep mountains, silently cultivating in solitude.

Again, in autumn, he went down the mountain to the village to beg for food. He saw that the trees gradually withered, frost and snow covered them, the leaves fell and froze, and even if he poked with his finger, the water in the ditches was exhausted and dried up.
At that time, the practitioner thought to himself:
Now, the myriad external things are all withered. Time does not return, and the flowers and trees do not flourish again. This saying is true!
He further saw in the human villages and cities, men and women, young and old, holding each other, disheveled hair hanging down, beating their chests and crying, unable to stop themselves.
At that time, the practitioner asked them:
Who are these people, wailing and crying to such an extent?
In such and such a village, the son or daughter of such and such a family died, or their parents passed away. This is why the village is crying in grief like this.
Having heard this, the practitioner thought to himself:
Now, these internal things are also withering away.

Having already understood the law of decline both internally and externally, he immediately returned to the deep mountains, internally reflecting on himself, sitting in full lotus position, either sitting on a rope bed or sitting under a tree, concentrating his mind and not giving rise to chaotic thoughts, contemplating the nature of the internal and external as truly impermanent, and then giving rise to the thought of the sun constantly turning without stopping.
What is meant by the turning of the sun?

Calculating from spring to autumn to a year, calculating from a year to a month, calculating from a month to a half-month, calculating from a half-month to the number of days, calculating from the number of days to the time, calculating from the time to day and night, calculating from day and night to movement, calculating from movement to coming and going, calculating from coming and going to the breath, calculating from the breath to the end without remainder, and reaching the end, only then knowing that the end is empty and myriad things do not exist.
Having already known non-existence, one then knows that arising has no origin, and cessation also leaves no trace.

Sometimes the practitioner's practice leaves traces when arising, but when ceasing, there are no traces. Only then does one awaken by oneself and recollect that the TathÄgata's everything is impermanent and also has no abode.

Sometimes practitioners observe the previous practices, accumulating for many days before they can be eliminated. They then recall the Buddha's words, that the TathÄgata also said that what is impermanent is suffering.
At that time, the practitioner reflects on himself:
Birth and death are like this, who would be willing to enjoy it?

The mind is already disgusted and not tainted by the four streams. Wishing to quickly attain nirvana and end the cycle of rebirth, they may attain the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, or arhatship in the meantime.

At that time, the World-Honored One observed with the pure divine eye, seeing that practitioner dwelling in the deep mountains, diligently studying the path and not cutting off the holy lineage. Based on this, he traced the roots and origins, showing great illumination for future beings, and also causing the true Dharma to long abide in the world. He then gathered the great assembly and spoke this verse:
The departed do not return, diligently striving day and night, like fish in a burning fire,
born with suffering and dying in calamity.
Human life is like day and night, sometimes still, sometimes moving in a circle,
Just like a swiftly flowing river, going and not returning.

The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, usually teach the Dharma, sometimes observing people's minds at appropriate times. Some sentient beings consider the body to be permanent, with the five aggregates of yesterday being no different from today. The ignorant are confused and think that the aggregates do not decline, just like a river flowing swiftly, with the previous flow not being the later flow and the later flow not being the previous flow, with those who leave forever gone and those who come not staying.

People are also like this, with the previous actions not being the later actions and the later actions not being the previous actions. At that time, the World-Honored One observed with his pure and immaculate heavenly eye and saw that the fourfold assembly was contemplating the formation and disintegration of the five aggregates.

At that time, the World-Honored One investigated the beginning and end, manifesting great illumination for the sake of future sentient beings, and also causing the true Dharma to long abide in the world.
At that time, the World-Honored One gathered the great assembly and spoke a verse, saying:
Human life is like day and night, sometimes still, sometimes revolving,
Just like a swiftly flowing river, going without returning.
The fourfold assembly, having heard what the Buddha said, rejoiced and departed.
Old age causes the complexion to fade, diseases destroy oneself, the body decays and rots,
Life ends in the same way.
Formerly, the Buddha was at the Potala Palace by the side of the Monkey Pond in the city of Vishali.
The Buddha told the bhikshus:

Some sentient beings rely on their youthful vigor and strength, thinking they are unrivaled. Some rely on being free from illness, thinking they are healthy and well. Some rely on their wealth and property, thinking they have immeasurable resources. Some rely on their noble status and family background, thinking they are accomplished. Some elders gather in the assembly, but are disparaged by others, considered worthless.
At that time, the World-Honored One observed that the minds of the people had right and wrong, and wanted to make the people change their past and cultivate the future, so he spoke this verse.

and when life ends, it is the same.

At that time, the World-Honored One, for the sake of people in the future, sought the root of this matter and manifested great illumination, causing the true Dharma to remain in the world for a long time. He then spoke a verse in the assembly:

The four groups in the assembly, hearing this teaching, gave rise to the thought of impermanence and no-self, or the mind of impurity and concentration, or mindfulness of breathing and guarding the mind, the stage of the summit, the stage of heat, the stage of patience, and the supreme worldly Dharma, or attained the fruit of stream-entry and the fruit of once-returning, or some gave rise to the aspiration for the unsurpassed path, or some aspired for the path of pratyekabuddha and arhat.

At that time, the great assembly, having heard the Buddha's teachings, departed with joy.
What is the use of this body?
It is always leaking and foul-smelling, afflicted by illness, and has the troubles of old age and death.

Among them, there was one person whose family lineage was the strongest, but his body was covered with sores and oozing pus and blood, day and night without rest, foul-smelling and impure, seen by all who covered their noses. In pain and agony, no one who saw him was not disgusted.
The Buddha knew his thoughts and told him:

The human body is composed of four elements, and the six sense faculties overflow, no different from those [impure things]. The entire human body is a house of suffering and affliction, filled with myriad worries and fears.

There are two reasons why the TathÄgata sends a message to receive the meal.

First, to give the Dharma talk to the devas, second, to look after the sick.

At that time, the World-Honored One looked around and saw that all the bhiká¹£us had accepted the invitation. He then took the key and opened a room, where he saw a bhiká¹£u lying in his own excrement and urine, unable to turn over.

What illness do you have that you are lying on a bed, unable to turn over in your own excrement and urine?
At that time, the bhiká¹£u, being honest and upright, without any deceit in his heart, replied to the World-Honored One,
By nature, I am dull-witted and always lazy. I never helped to look after others. Therefore, no one is looking after me now. I am truly alone and destitute, with no one to rely on.

At that time, the World-Honored One personally carried him out to the door, removed the impurities, washed the sitting mat, took clean water to wash his body, put on his clothes, spread out a new sitting mat, and brought him back to the room. The TathÄgata himself extended his hand as a pillow and said to the bhiká¹£u:

You should not slack off in seeking the supreme Dharma. You have not yet attained what should be attained, and have not yet received the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a's practice. If you do not apply yourself to receiving this Dharma, you will have to undergo even more severe suffering.

At that time, the World-Honored One gradually spoke the most wonderful Dharma to him, and with countless skillful means encouraged him to be courageous and contemplate the Way and virtue. He then rose from his seat, returned to his room, went to the assembly hall, and instructed the attendant:
You should now quickly gather all the bhiká¹£us present in ÅšrÄvastÄ« and go to the assembly hall.
When the bhiká¹£us had gathered, the World-Honored One said:
You bhiká¹£us!

There are no fathers, no mothers, no brothers, no sisters, and also no relatives or five kinds of close relatives. Not looking after each other, each abandoning the other, this is not appropriate. It will be seen as ridiculed by non-Buddhist practitioners and Brahmins:
'The Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama has not a single hair of compassion. He regards human life as if it were tiles and stones. The dead are orphaned and destitute, with no one to care for them.
' Our Dharma is well-ordered, with harmony between superiors and inferiors. If you do this, you will be defeated by them.

From now on, disciples should serve their teachers as they would their parents, not abandoning them until death. Teachers should care for their disciples as if they were their own children, taking care of them according to the times, not abandoning them until death. The mutual kindness between teachers and disciples flows on for endless kalpas. All possessions should be distributed equally. If there are no possessions, one should go to the houses of the generous and encourage them to cultivate merit.
If one has few acquaintances, one should go to the merchants' houses to beg for alms. The good food should be given to the sick, and the bad food should be eaten by oneself.
Those who care for the sick are caring for my body, and the merit they gain is also no different.
Then, not long after the World-Honored One left, the sick monk thought to himself:
This body of the four great elements is a gathering of much suffering. What use is it?
It is full of impurities and afflicted by illness, not free from old age and death.
It is appropriate to be careful and practice the Buddha's words.

At that time, many monks opened the door with the key-mother and saw that the monk had already abandoned his body. They then told the World-Honored One:
The sick monk has now passed away. We do not know where his spirit has been reborn.
In what kind of path is he?
The Buddha told the monks:

That sick monk had long accumulated wholesome practices. I taught him the Dharma and his mind was enlightened. Later, his mind became fierce, and he contemplated the Dharma according to the Dharma, discerning the profound Dharma.
This son of a good family has already attained nirvana, you should make offerings to his relics.

At that time, the World-Honored One, having contemplated this meaning, wished to cause the true Dharma to remain in the world for a long time, and to show great illumination to future sentient beings. He spoke a verse in the great assembly:
What use is this body?
It is always leaking and foul-smelling, afflicted by illness, and has the troubles of old age and death.
When sentient beings heard the Dharma, they joyfully accepted and practiced it.
This body is leaking and foul-smelling, a gathering place for many illnesses,
Without troubles, the foremost cessation, peaceful and eternally at rest.

This body is a stinking and filthy place, a multitude of afflictions and impurities that people dislike seeing, the head of all the impure multitudes of painful leaks and wounds, impermanent and subject to change and destruction, the suffering within suffering is none greater than the aggregates. One should seek skillful means to leave the body of the four elements, skillfully planning and seeking the essential, all afflictions forever cease without remainder, thus it is called exhaustion.
Having already exhausted emptiness, it is empty and tranquil, also without the two of arising, ceasing, attachment, or cutting off.
Without affliction, the foremost cessation is peaceful and without thoughts of worry or joy, peacefully and eternally at rest, the foremost cessation and extinction without remainder, nirvana.
At that time, those in the assembly who heard this teaching rejoiced and accepted it, made obeisance, and left.
When it's hot, stay here; when it's cold and snowy, stay here. Fools have many premonitions,
but don't know what changes will come.

In the past, there was an elder who built a house with halls for the four seasons, each according to his own preference, not observing the precepts. For the three months of the year, he did not make any preparations. He was wealthy beyond count, but stingy and greedy, not giving to anyone. He also did not provide for Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as;

He did not believe in the present world or the next world, indulging in self-indulgence, stingy and difficult to transform, not recognizing morality and virtue, not considering impermanence. He built another fine room, with a front porch and a back hall, a cool terrace and a warm room for winter, with dozens of rooms built on the east and west sides, and suddenly became impermanent due to a wind illness.

The Buddha, with his pure heavenly eye free from defilements, saw that this elder suddenly passed away. While alive, he had no compassionate kindness to benefit sentient beings, but only exhausted the people with labor. His intentions and plans were ultimately not fulfilled.

At that time, the World-Honored One, in the midst of the great assembly, wishing to manifest its meaning and proclaim the original source, also causing future sentient beings to understand well without doubt, further manifesting the divine mouth seal of the past Buddha-World-Honored Ones, which was sealed, also causing the true Dharma to long abide in the world, he then gathered the great assembly and spoke a verse, saying:
In summer, stay here; in winter and snow, stay here. The foolish have many anticipations,
Not knowing the changes to come.
At that time, those in the assembly, hearing what the Buddha said, joyfully undertook to practice it.
Rejoicing in giving birth to a child, with attachment not separating, drunk, encountering a violent river,
Drowning, losing one's body and life.

In the past, there was a householder who was extremely wealthy, with countless treasures filling his house and storehouses. He possessed the seven treasures of gold, silver, precious stones, agate, pearls, tiger-patterned amber, and so forth. He had servants, elephants, horses, carriages, and granaries, all without shortage. However, he lacked an heir to carry on his lineage.

Because of his lack of a son, he prayed to various gods, kneeling before the gods of the house, the city, the streets, and other gods. He also knelt before the gods of his ancestors, parents, mountains, trees, heaven and earth, and even down to the gods of filthy tombs. He bowed to all of them, but his wish was not fulfilled and he still had no son. He became increasingly ill from the grief and worry of day and night.

Now, the treasures in my house are countless, and rare treasures are all in my house. Moreover, I have no heir to carry on my lineage. If I die, all my wealth will be confiscated by the government. Thinking of this, I am deeply saddened and do not know what to do.

This person was fortunate, and the illness gradually subsided. In less than a month, he gave birth to a son who was upright and unparalleled, a rarity in the world, with a face like a peach blossom and all the auspicious marks.

The parents, seeing this, were overjoyed and could not contain themselves. They invited the people from the neighboring villages to feast and celebrate, with singing and dancing, enjoying themselves all day, or indulging in sleep without knowing anything.
At that time, there was a great flood that swept away everything, leaving no survivors.

At that time, the World-Honored One, with his pure divine eye free from defilements, saw the rise and fall of this elder. Based on this cause and condition, he investigated the root and origin, wishing to enable sentient beings in the future to understand without doubt. He also manifested the divine seal of the past Buddha World-Honored Ones, which was sealed, and also caused the true Dharma to remain in the world for a long time. He then gathered the great assembly and spoke a verse, saying:
Joyful at the birth of a child, with love and attachment not letting go, drunk, encountering a violent river,
Drowning, losing one's body and life.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard what the Buddha said, and joyfully upheld it in practice.
Having children and wealth, the fool is only anxious, life is not mine,
How can there be children and wealth?
The ignorant and foolish, consider themselves wise, the fool who claims to be wise, is called the ultimate fool.

At that time, many young boys were skilled in archery, with arrows touching each other, they were the best in archery, and they prided themselves on their high family lineage, being unmatched in the world.

The son further thought to himself:
My father has skills that will surely surpass everyone else.
They relied on each other and did not save themselves. When impermanence arrived, they scattered to different places.
Therefore, the verse says:
In the midst of a crowd, looking at relatives and siblings,
They are chased by the messengers of death, and when struck, there is no retreat.
The messengers of death have many kinds, and relatives are there to rescue,
But accumulated wealth is countless, and they are disturbed by thieves.
A raging fire is extinguished by water, and that light is removed by a cover,
Anger is removed by poison, and sorcery removes evil.
A rampaging elephant is pulled by a hook, and cattle are led by a staff,
This crowd all has happiness, but impermanence is difficult to rely on.
The power of impermanence is untrustworthy. Knowing that death is imminent,
But it will not last long.
All will be exhausted, with no one aware, reviled by the world, wandering through the realms.

Many beings have different aspirations and do different things, and the wholesome roots they cultivate are also not worth mentioning. Their minds are attached to external affairs and do not think of inner dharmas, not thinking of the death of life, their minds always reckoning permanence.

Give generously, uphold the precepts, and cultivate various wholesome roots. In life, you will have a good reputation and after death, you will fall into a good realm.
The younger brother replied to his elder brother:

Leaving the household life to become a monk, you do not worry about official matters, do not think of your father, brothers, wife, and children, and also do not think of your family business or wealth and treasures.
If you are insulted, you do not harbor sorrow or distress, and if you encounter joy and pleasure, you do not feel delighted.
He was often admonished but did not follow his elder brother's teachings.
Later, the younger brother encountered illness and suddenly passed away. He was reborn as an ox and was driven by people to carry salt into the city.
At that time, the elder brother, an arhat, came out of the city and spoke a verse to the ox, saying:
Bearing a heavy load on your back, walking the road without rest,
Being driven by others, today is a day of leisure and play.
Having a pierced nose and being tethered, with a back full of boils and sores,
Being bitten by flies, today is a day of leisure and play.
Eating poor grass, drinking rainwater,
Never leaving the body of the whip, today is a day of leisure and play.
Having taken on the form of an animal, what expedient means do you practice?
Can you focus your thoughts on the virtues of the Three Jewels?
When the cow heard this, it sadly wept and was unhappy.
The cowherd said to the monk:

The monk replied:

The cowherd heard this and said to the monk:

The arhat said:
In the past, your younger brother owed me a penny's worth of salt.
At that time, the owner of the ox said to the ox:
I now release you and will not make you work again.
Then the ox threw itself into a deep ravine, single-mindedly thinking of the Buddha, and immediately ended its life and was reborn in the heavens.

There are sentient beings who deeply yearn for worldly entanglements and are attached to wealth and goods, not cultivating wholesome conduct. When their bodies perish and their lives end, they are reborn among hungry ghosts;
Or there are people who leave home to study the Way, abandon affection and love, and give up the world's eight dharmas to cultivate pure intentions.

It is like King Tai's son, the daughter of the Chanda people. Her body was adorned with fragrant necklaces, and her appearance was upright, like a heavenly maiden. She wanted to marry her, but the king replied:
The law of a king does not marry outsiders. He does not marry with the common people, but always marries with elders and householders.
The prince said to the king:
If I cannot marry this woman, I will now kill myself. I cannot bear to live in the world.

The prince said to the king:
What I crave and enjoy, I must learn the killing method, and do not consider it difficult.

The prince replied:

The prince shed tears, feeling sad and unhappy.
This analogy is beneficial in many ways.

There may be princes, elders, and householders who leave home to study the Way, diligently cultivating merit and virtue, seeking to become arhats, free from worldly bonds and attachments, detached from desires, liberated from both this world and the next, discerning ignorance, with wisdom and liberation, attaining the precious meaning of liberation without doubt.
Parents, siblings, and others reprimand those who have left home, saying:
There is nothing more despised among people than the path. Begging from house to house is taken as normal, and people laugh at it. How can it be bearable or enjoyable?
People curse each other, making you become a beggar. It is better to stay at home and enjoy the five desires.
